query: Where can I find the actual Titanic passenger survival data? Is there a historical database with all passenger outcomes?

results.title: ANSWER
results.text: You can download the complete individual‑level passenger‑outcome data from the CRAN “titanic” package (which mirrors the original Kaggle files) or from the public “Titanic Passenger List” database at Encyclopedia‑Titanica.org, which provides the full manifest with survival status. ([cran.r‑project.org](https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/titanic/index.html), [encyclopedia‑titanica.org](https://encyclopedia-titanica.org/titanic-passenger-list))

results.title: titanic: Titanic Passenger Survival Data Set
results.text:
## titanic: Titanic Passenger Survival Data Set

This data set provides information on the fate of passengers on
the fatal maiden voyage of the ocean liner "Titanic", summarized according
to economic status (class), sex, age and survival. Whereas the base R
Titanic data found by calling data("Titanic") is an array resulting from
cross-tabulating 2201 observations, these data sets are the individual
non-aggregated observations and formatted in a machine learning context
with a training sample, a testing sample, and two additional data sets
that can be used for deeper machine learning analysis. These data sets
are also the data sets downloaded from the Kaggle competition and thus
lowers the barrier to entry for users new to R or machine learing.

|     |     |
| --- | --- |
| Version: | 0.1.0 |
| Depends: | R (≥ 3.1.2) |
| Suggests: | [dplyr](https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/dplyr/index.html) |
| Published: | 2015-08-31 |
| DOI: | [10.32614/CRAN.package.titanic](https://doi.org/10.32614/CRAN.package.titanic) |
| Author: | Paul Hendricks \[aut, cre\] |
| Maintainer: | Paul Hendricks <paul.hendricks.2013 at owu.edu> |
| BugReports: | [https://github.com/paulhendricks/titanic/issues](https://github.com/paulhendricks/titanic/issues) |
| License: | [CC0](https://creativecommons.org/publicdomain/zero/1.0/legalcode) |
| URL: | [https://github.com/paulhendricks/titanic](https://github.com/paulhendricks/titanic) |
| NeedsCompilation: | no |
| Materials: | [README](https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/titanic/readme/README.html) |
| CRAN checks: | [titanic results](https://cran.r-project.org/web/checks/check_results_titanic.html) |

#### Documentation:

|     |     |
| --- | --- |
| Reference manual: | [titanic.pdf](https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/titanic/titanic.pdf) |

#### Downloads:

| --- | --- |
| Package source: | [titanic\_0.1.0.tar.gz](https://cran.r-project.org/src/contrib/titanic_0.1.0.tar.gz) |
| Windows binaries: | r-devel: [titanic\_0.1.0.zip](https://cran.r-project.org/bin/windows/contrib/4.5/titanic_0.1.0.zip), r-release: [titanic\_0.1.0.zip](https://cran.r-project.org/bin/windows/contrib/4.4/titanic_0.1.0.zip), r-oldrel: [titanic\_0.1.0.zip](https://cran.r-project.org/bin/windows/contrib/4.3/titanic_0.1.0.zip) |
| macOS binaries: | r-release (arm64): [titanic\_0.1.0.tgz](https://cran.r-project.org/bin/macosx/big-sur-arm64/contrib/4.4/titanic_0.1.0.tgz), r-oldrel (arm64): [titanic\_0.1.0.tgz](https://cran.r-project.org/bin/macosx/big-sur-arm64/contrib/4.3/titanic_0.1.0.tgz), r-release (x86\_64): [titanic\_0.1.0.tgz](https://cran.r-project.org/bin/macosx/big-sur-x86_64/contrib/4.4/titanic_0.1.0.tgz), r-oldrel (x86\_64): [titanic\_0.1.0.tgz](https://cran.r-project.org/bin/macosx/big-sur-x86_64/contrib/4.3/titanic_0.1.0.tgz) |

#### Reverse dependencies:

| --- | --- |
| Reverse imports: | [D3partitionR](https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/D3partitionR/index.html), [rfVarImpOOB](https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/rfVarImpOOB/index.html) |
| Reverse suggests: | [dataCompareR](https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/dataCompareR/index.html), [hpa](https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/hpa/index.html), [ibawds](https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/ibawds/index.html), [marginaleffects](https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/marginaleffects/index.html), [xgboost](https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/xgboost/index.html) |

Package ‘tidytitanic’
July 22, 2025
Title Dataframes Based on Titanic Passengers and Crew
Version 0.0.1
Description
A version of the Titanic survival data tailored for people analytics demonstrations and practice. While another package, 'titanic', reproduces the Kaggle competition files with minimal preprocessing, 'tidytitanic' combines the train and test datasets into the single dataset, 'passengers', for exploration and summary across all passengers. It also extracts personal identifiers—such as first names, last names, and titles from the raw 'name' field, enabling demographic analysis. The 'passengers' data does not cover the crew, but this package also provides the more bare-bones, crew-containing datasets 'tidy_titanic' and 'flat_titanic' based on the 'Titanic' data set from 'datasets' for further exploration. This human-centered data package is designed to support exploratory data analysis, feature engineering, and pedagogical use cases.
License MIT + file LICENSE
Encoding UTF-8
LazyData true
RoxygenNote 7.3.1
Depends R (>= 2.10)
NeedsCompilation no
Author Evangeline Reynolds [aut, cre]
Maintainer Evangeline Reynolds <evangeline.mae@gmail.com>
Repository CRAN
Date/Publication 2025-07-11 12:30:07 UTC
Contents

results.title: titanic: Titanic Passenger Survival Data Set
results.text:
# Package: titanic 0.1.0.9000

## titanic: Titanic Passenger Survival Data Set

This data set provides information on the fate of
passengers on the fatal maiden voyage of the ocean liner
"Titanic", with variables such as economic status (class), sex,
age, and survival. Whereas the base R Titanic data found by
calling data("Titanic") is an array resulting from
cross-tabulating 2201 observations, these data sets are
individual non-aggregated observations and formatted in a
machine learning context with a training sample, a testing
sample, and two additional data sets that can be used for
deeper machine learning analysis. These data sets are used in a
very well known Kaggle competition; formatting the raw data
sets in a package hopefully lowers the barrier to entry for
users new to R and machine learning.

Authors:Paul Hendricks \[aut, cre\]

[titanic\_0.1.0.9000.tar.gz](https://paulhendricks.r-universe.dev/src/contrib/titanic_0.1.0.9000.tar.gz)

[titanic\_0.1.0.9000.zip](https://paulhendricks.r-universe.dev/bin/windows/contrib/4.6/titanic_0.1.0.9000.zip)(r-4.6) [titanic\_0.1.0.9000.zip](https://paulhendricks.r-universe.dev/bin/windows/contrib/4.5/titanic_0.1.0.9000.zip)(r-4.5) [titanic\_0.1.0.9000.zip](https://paulhendricks.r-universe.dev/bin/windows/contrib/4.4/titanic_0.1.0.9000.zip)(r-4.4)

[titanic\_0.1.0.9000.tgz](https://paulhendricks.r-universe.dev/bin/macosx/big-sur-x86_64/contrib/4.5/titanic_0.1.0.9000.tgz)(r-4.5-any) [titanic\_0.1.0.9000.tgz](https://paulhendricks.r-universe.dev/bin/macosx/big-sur-x86_64/contrib/4.4/titanic_0.1.0.9000.tgz)(r-4.4-any)

[titanic\_0.1.0.9000.tar.gz](https://paulhendricks.r-universe.dev/bin/linux/noble-x86_64/4.6/src/contrib/titanic_0.1.0.9000.tar.gz)(r-4.6-any) [titanic\_0.1.0.9000.tar.gz](https://paulhendricks.r-universe.dev/bin/linux/noble-x86_64/4.5/src/contrib/titanic_0.1.0.9000.tar.gz)(r-4.5-any)

[titanic\_0.1.0.9000.tgz](https://paulhendricks.r-universe.dev/bin/emscripten/contrib/4.4/titanic_0.1.0.9000.tgz)(r-4.4-emscripten)

[titanic.pdf](https://paulhendricks.r-universe.dev/titanic/titanic.pdf) \| [titanic.html](https://paulhendricks.r-universe.dev/titanic/doc/manual.html) ✨

[titanic/json](https://paulhendricks.r-universe.dev/api/packages/titanic) (API)

|     |
| --- |
| # Install 'titanic' in R: |
| install.packages('titanic', repos = c('https://paulhendricks.r-universe.dev', 'https://cloud.r-project.org')) |

Bug tracker:[https://github.com/paulhendricks/titanic/issues](https://github.com/paulhendricks/titanic/issues)

Datasets:

- [titanic\_gender\_class\_model](https://paulhendricks.r-universe.dev/titanic/doc/manual.html#titanic_gender_class_model) _\- Titanic gender class model data._
- [titanic\_gender\_model](https://paulhendricks.r-universe.dev/titanic/doc/manual.html#titanic_gender_model) _\- Titanic gender model data._
- [titanic\_test](https://paulhendricks.r-universe.dev/titanic/doc/manual.html#titanic_test) _\- Titanic test data._
- [titanic\_train](https://paulhendricks.r-universe.dev/titanic/doc/manual.html#titanic_train) _\- Titanic train data._

results.title: Press Release
results.text:
Press Release https://archives.gov/press/press-releases/1998-271
Press Release
None
2013-01-30T20:02:47-05:00
# Press ReleasePress Release · Tuesday, June 2, 1998
**Press Release** **June 2, 1998** **National Archives Makes Available Additional Records Relating to _R.M.S. Titanic_ Disaster**
Washington, DC . . .The National Archives and Records Administration (NARA) announces that it is making additional microfilm records relating to the sinking of the _R.M.S. Titanic_ available at NARA facilities throughout the United States and on the World Wide Web. The records contain the names of some 400 of the more than 700 passengers rescued by the passenger steamship _S.S. Carpathia_ from the _Titanic_ disaster site.
Although _Carpathia_ returned to New York on April 18, 1912, the list of survivors is filed with manifests dated two months later. It can be found on NARA microfilm publication T715, "Passenger and Crew Lists of Vessels Arriving at New York, 1897-1957," roll 1883 (INS Volume 4183). The list was recorded on a standard manifest form and contains 29 columns of information, including age, occupation, address, nearest relative or friend, destination, physical description, and place of birth.
Pages reproduced from the microfilm are now on display at the National Archives - Pacific Region (Laguna Niguel). The microfilm can be viewed at the National Archives Building downtown in Washington, DC, and at the regional facilities nationwide, and is available on the NARA website at [http://www.archives.gov/](https://archives.gov/index.html). The public may call (202) 501-5400 for more information about obtaining copies of the document. Sample paper copies of the microfilm will be available for the press by calling (301) 837-1700.
For additional PRESS information, please contact the National Archives Public Affairs staff at (301) 837-1700 or by [e-mail](mailto:public.affairs@nara.gov).
98-94
This page was last reviewed on January 30, 2013.
[Contact us with questions or comments](https://archives.gov/contact).
[Top](https://archives.gov/press/press-releases/1998-271#page-header)

results.text:
| | | --- | | * * *
# Statistical Consultants Ltd
* * * | | | | --- | | [![Home](https://www.statisticalconsultants.co.nz/Buttons/Home%20A.png)](https://www.statisticalconsultants.co.nz/)[![Services](https://www.statisticalconsultants.co.nz/Buttons/Services%20A.png)](https://www.statisticalconsultants.co.nz/services.html)[![Blog](https://www.statisticalconsultants.co.nz/Buttons/Blog%20A.png)](https://www.statisticalconsultants.co.nz/blog.html)[![Links](https://www.statisticalconsultants.co.nz/Buttons/Links%20A.png)](https://www.statisticalconsultants.co.nz/links.html)[![About](https://www.statisticalconsultants.co.nz/Buttons/About%20A.png)](https://www.statisticalconsultants.co.nz/about.html)[![Contact](https://www.statisticalconsultants.co.nz/Buttons/Contact%20A.png)](https://www.statisticalconsultants.co.nz/contact.html) | | | | | | --- | --- | | | | # **Titanic Survival Data** * * * _Data Tables_ _Date posted:_ 23 April 2012 * * * ![Titanic](https://www.statisticalconsultants.co.nz/blog/B47/titanic.jpg) The RMS Titanic sank on 15 April 1912, in the North Atlantic Ocean while on its maiden voyage, travelling from South Hampton, UK to New York, USA. The number of fatalities is uncertain due to several reasons including: - Double counting caused by people using aliases - The final passenger list not having been updated to account for every person who cancelled their trip Another reason for inconsistent data, is that some people died (as a result of injuries or exposure) after they were picked up by the rescue ship (the RMS Carpathia). * * * ## **Titanic Survival** **Data Summarised by Class, Age Group and Sex** | Class | Age Group | Sex | Number
Survived | Number
Aboard | Percent
Survived | | 1st | child | male | 5 | 5 | 100.0 | | 2nd | child | male | 11 | 11 | 100.0 | | 3rd | child | male | 13 | 48 | 27.1 | | 1st | adult | male | 57 | 175 | 32.6 | | 2nd | adult | male | 14 | 168 | 8.3 | | 3rd | adult | male | 75 | 462 | 16.2 | | Crew | adult | male | 192 | 862 | 22.3 | | 1st | child | female | 1 | 1 | 100.0 | | 2nd | child | female | 13 | 13 | 100.0 | | 3rd | child | female | 14 | 31 | 45.2 | | 1st | adult | female | 140 | 144 | 97.2 | | 2nd | adult | female | 80 | 93 | 86.0 | | 3rd | adult | female | 76 | 165 | 46.1 | | Crew | adult | female | 20 | 23 | 87.0 | | TOTAL | 711 | 2201 | 32.3 | Data Source: The _Titanic_ data set, in the _datasets_ library in the statistical software R. * * * ## **Graph of Titanic** **Survival Rates by Age** A LOESS smoother was added to the plot. ![Graph of Titanic survival rates by age](https://www.statisticalconsultants.co.nz/blog/B47/titanic-survival-rates-by-age.png) Data _Source:_ Encyclopedia Titanica * * * ## **Titanic Survival Data Summarised by Title** By using some simple text mining techniques, the titles were extracted from the names of the individuals (survivors and victims) in the Encyclopedia Titanica data set. | Title | Number Survived | Number Aboard | Percent
Survived | | Mr | 315 | 1588 | 19.8 | | Mrs | 165 | 210 | 78.6 | | Ms | 2 | 2 | 100.0 | | Master | 31 | 61 | 50.8 | | Miss | 185 | 270 | 68.5 | | Mme. | 1 | 1 | 100.0 | | Mlle | 2 | 2 | 100.0 | | Sig. | 0 | 43 | 0.0 | | Sir | 1 | 1 | 100.0 | | Lady | 1 | 1 | 100.0 | | Countess | 1 | 1 | 100.0 | | Don | 0 | 1 | 0.0 | | Doña | 1 | 1 | 100.0 | | Fr | 0 | 7 | 0.0 | | Rev | 0 | 1 | 0.0 | | Captain | 0 | 2 | 0.0 | | Colonel | 2 | 4 | 50.0 | | Major | 1 | 2 | 50.0 | | Dr | 4 | 10 | 40.0 | | TOTAL | 712 | 2208 | 32.2 | _Data Source:_ Encyclopedia Titanica * * * ## **Titanic Crew Survival** **Data Summarised by** **Department** | Department | Number
Survived | Number
Aboard | Percent
Survived | | A
la Carte (restaurant
staff) | 3 | 69 | 4.3 | | Deck | 43 | 66 | 65.2 | | Engine | 72 | 325 | 22.2 | | Victualling | 94 | 431 | 21.8 | | TOTAL | 212 | 891 | 23.8 | Data _Source:_ Encyclopedia Titanica * * * ## **Titanic** **Embarking Location Data** | | Class | | | Embarked at: | crew | first | second | third | TOTAL | | Unknown | 0 | 3 | 0 | 0 | 3 | | Belfast | 188 | 4 | 6 | 0 | 198 | | Southampton | 703 | 171 | 246 | 493 | 1613 | | Cherbourg | 0 | 146 | 26 | 102 | 274 | | Queenstown | 0 | 0 | 7 | 113 | 120 | | TOTAL | 891 | 324 | 285 | 708 | | | Embarked
at: | Number Survived | Number Aboard | Percent Survived | | Unknown | 2 | 3 | 66.7 | | Belfast | 43 | 198 | 21.7 | | Southampton | 469 | 1613 | 29.1 | | Cherbourg | 156 | 274 | 56.9 | | Queenstown | 42 | 120 | 35.0 | | TOTAL | 712 | 2208 | 32.2 | Data _Source:_ Encyclopedia Titanica * * * ### **_**_External link:_**_** [Encyclopedia Titanica](https://www.encyclopedia-titanica.org) ### **_See_** **_also:_** [Titanic\ Fare Data](https://www.statisticalconsultants.co.nz/blog/titanic-fare-data.html) [Battle\ of Britain Casualty Data](https://www.statisticalconsultants.co.nz/blog/battle-of-britain-casualty-data.html) * * * | | | | --- | | [![Home](https://www.statisticalconsultants.co.nz/Buttons/Home%20A.png)](https://www.statisticalconsultants.co.nz/)[![Services](https://www.statisticalconsultants.co.nz/Buttons/Services%20A.png)](https://www.statisticalconsultants.co.nz/services.html)[![Blog](https://www.statisticalconsultants.co.nz/Buttons/Blog%20A.png)](https://www.statisticalconsultants.co.nz/blog.html)[![Links](https://www.statisticalconsultants.co.nz/Buttons/Links%20A.png)](https://www.statisticalconsultants.co.nz/links.html)[![About](https://www.statisticalconsultants.co.nz/Buttons/About%20A.png)](https://www.statisticalconsultants.co.nz/about.html)[![Contact](https://www.statisticalconsultants.co.nz/Buttons/Contact%20A.png)](https://www.statisticalconsultants.co.nz/contact.html) | | | | --- | | Copyright

results.title: GitHub - harbidel/TITANIC: The historical data has been split into two groups, a 'training set' and a 'test set'. For the training set, we provide the outcome ( 'ground truth' ) for each passenger. You will use this set to build your model to generate predictions for the test set.  For each passenger in the test set, you must predict whether or not they survived the sinking ( 0 for deceased, 1 for survived ). Your score is the percentage of passengers you correctly predict.  The leaderboard has a public and private component. 50% of your predictions for the test set have been randomly assigned to the public leaderboard ( the same 50% for all users ). Your score on this public portion is what will appear on the leaderboard. At the end of the contest, we will reveal your score on the private 50% of the data, which will determine the final winner. This method prevents users from 'overfitting' to the leaderboard.  Data Description  Overview The data has been split into two groups: training set (train.csv) test set (test.csv)  The training set should be used to build your machine learning models. For the training set, we provide the outcome (also known as the “ground truth”) for each passenger. Your model will be based on “features” like passengers’ gender and class. You can also use feature engineering to create new features.  The test set should be used to see how well your model performs on unseen data. For the test set, we do not provide the ground truth for each passenger. It is your job to predict these outcomes. For each passenger in the test set, use the model you trained to predict whether or not they survived the sinking of the Titanic.  Data Dictionary Variable Definition Key  survival Survival 0 = No, 1 = Yes  pclass Ticket class 1 = 1st, 2 = 2nd, 3 = 3rd  sex Sex  Age Age in years  sibsp # of siblings / spouses aboard the Titanic
